author: @gregf9160
text: In all SQL, text-based select values must be either converted to upper or lower otherwise the value you are selecting is case sensitive. Some databases allow you to turn case-sensitivity off (COLLATE in SQLITE) but otherwise, 'PYTHON' and 'Python' and 'python' are literal.  So you might do SELECT * FROM TABLE WHERE LOWER(KEYWORD) = 'python'  ...or   SELECT * FROM TABLE WHERE UPPER(KEYWORD) = 'PYTHON'  ... or  SELECT * FROM TABLE WHERE KEYWORD = 'python' COLLATE NOCASE   I would use COLLATE NOCASE in preference to UPPER() or LOWER() as they probably have a slight conversion overhead -- as _any_ string conversion function does -- whereas COLLATE NOCASE is perhaps more efficient.
